channel.title: Stories from onezero.medium.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best onezero.medium.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Zen And The Art Of Searching For Lost Computer Files
item.description: Spend your quarantine digging through your digital attic.
item.kicker: NOW THAT YOU HAVE THE TIME

item.title: I Got My Pandemic Mantra From 'World Of Warcraft'
item.description: "You feel normal." "You feel normal." "You feel normal."

item.title: Scientists Are Racing To Get Us Faster, Simpler Coronavirus Tests
item.description: Rapid and at-home tests could give results in minutes rather than days.

item.title: Silicon Valley's #MeToo Moment Didn't Change Anything
item.description: The missteps of tech culture, most women say, remains a discussion that doesn't easily traverse gender lines.
item.kicker: DISRUPTION FOR ME, NOT FOR THEE

item.title: Zoom Burnout Is Real
item.description: And here's what to do about it.

item.title: An MIT Lab Is Building Devices To Hack Your Dreams
item.description: From improving your mood to focusing your creativity, scientists at MIT's Dream Lab want to prove the power of dreams.
item.kicker: DREAM A LITTLE DREAM OF MIT

item.title: Amazon Is At War With Its Workers
item.description: A surge of protests has demanded safer conditions during the coronavirus pandemic. But will they make a difference?

item.title: The World's Smartphones Are Filled With Gold. That's A Problem
item.description: Small amounts of gold used in electronics quickly add up to environmental and humanitarian disasters.

item.title: We Mapped How The Coronavirus Is Driving New Surveillance Programs Around The World
item.description: At least 28 countries are ramping up surveillance to combat the coronavirus.
item.kicker: KEEPING AN EYE —OR TWO — ON THINGS

item.title: Binaural Beats Promise Enlightenment. Mostly, They're Just Noise
item.description: I spent one week using binaural beats and came away unchanged.

item.title: Our Government Runs On A 60-Year-Old Coding Language, And Now It's Falling Apart
item.description: Over the weekend, New Jersey governor Phil Murphy made an unusual public plea during his daily coronavirus briefing: The state was seeking volunteer programmers who know COBOL.

item.title: Do Personal Carbon Credits Work?
item.description: I'm paying Project Wren $15.70 per month to offset my carbon footprint. Can it do more than absolve my guilt?

item.title: Jealousy, Rumors And Suspicion: How Facebook Disaster Groups Turn On Themselves
item.description: The Paradise Fire Adopt a Family Facebook group had almost 30,000 members helping and seeking help. Then it imploded.

item.title: Data Thieves Are Targeting Dead People's Social Media Accounts
item.description: In 2012, the family of a deceased soldier in the United States was blindsided when they started seeing his face on ads for dating websites. What's going on?

item.title: I Lived Off Homemade Soylent For A Week During A Global Crisis
item.description: While some out here are leaning hard into home cooking, it might actually be a good time to perfect self-sustenance.

item.title: That Viral Drone Date Guy's Story Doesn't Quite Check Out
item.description: We talked to him, and the clip might be a bit less spontaneous than advertised.

item.title: This Is What The Earth's Climate Will Look Like In 2050
item.description: The future under climate change can seem frighteningly vague and variable. A top climatologist explains what to expect in 2050.

item.title: The Surface Pro X Should Scare Apple
item.description: There's finally competition for Apple in a space where for a long time there weren't any good alternatives.

item.title: Doctors Find Instant YouTube Fame During The Coronavirus
item.description: Even Dr. Pimple Popper is tackling the coronavirus.

item.title: Lemons For Yeast For Flour: The Bartering Economy Explodes On Nextdoor
item.description: Nextdoor suddenly looks like Oregon Trail 2.0.

item.title: As Disasters Mount, Our Cities May Need To Move Underground
item.description: Temperatures are rising and urban centers are packed. To preserve livable societies, some argue we should build "Earthscrapers."

item.title: The Free Email Service That Broke The News Of The Coronavirus In 2019
item.description: ProMED previously spotted outbreaks of MERS, Zika, and Ebola. And they were on top of COVID-19 in December.

item.title: I Got My File From Clearview AI, And It Freaked Me Out
item.description: Here's how you might be able to get yours.

item.title: There's Only One Way To 'Disappear' On The Internet These Days
item.description: To kill my digital self, I had to create an army of clones.
item.kicker: A COPY OF A COPY OF A COPY

item.title: I Turned Pixel-Perfect Cities Into Psychedelic Hellscapes Using Machine Learning
item.description: Look, I may have accidentally summoned some demons from the pixel art underworld. I don't know what is happening to these little creatures, but it sure doesn't look good.

item.title: It's Time To Resurrect The Airship Hospitals
item.description: An idea devised to beat the tuberculosis pandemic 100 years ago could apply to coronavirus.

item.title: We Asked An AI To Write A Column For Us. The Results Were Wild
item.description: GPT-210, as we call it, has some serious writing chops.
item.kicker: GIVING THE ROBOTS OUR JOBS... SMH

item.title: Folding Smartphones May Fix Your Distracted Mind
item.description: They're slightly less efficient, and that's a good thing.

item.title: I Did A 24-Hour Dopamine Fast And I Felt Everything, Not Nothing
item.description: I do not subscribe to Silicon Valley's idea of wellness, which arguably makes me a kind of ideal subject for dopamine fasting. If dopamine fasting truly is hacking your brain chemistry, then it should work on me regardless of my own biases, right?
item.kicker: THE BRAIN WANTS WHAT IT WANTS

item.title: How To Build The Speedy Home Wi-Fi Network Of Your Dreams
item.description: Even if you're paying for decent internet, there's always that one corner of the house where Netflix stutters and buffers.
item.kicker: NOW THAT WE ALL WORK FROM HOME

item.title: A Battery Breakthrough Could End Lithium-Ion's Reign
item.description: Potassium batteries are coming for the throne.

item.title: The US Fears Live Facial Recognition. In Buenos Aires, It's A Fact Of Life
item.description: Live facial recognition has been in use in the capital of Argentina for nearly a year.

item.title: My Summer Internship At Google Turned Me Off Silicon Valley Forever
item.description: I had never seen the TV show "Silicon Valley," though I heard it was hilarious and alarmingly close to reality. I probably should have watched it before I decided to go.

item.title: The Untold Story Of The Man That Made Mainstream Encryption Possible
item.description: Whit Diffie didn't read until he was 10 years old. There was no question of disability, he simply preferred that his parents read to him, which seemingly they did, quite patiently. Finally, in the fifth grade, Diffie spontaneously worked his way through a tome called "The Space Cat," and immediately progressed to the "Oz" books

item.title: Classic iPod Hackers Say There's No Better Way To Listen To Music
item.description: Apple may have discontinued the last of the click-wheel iPods years ago, but a large community of iPod modders resurrects them for their sound and nostalgia.

item.title: The Definitive Ranking of Silicon Valley Shoes
item.description: Tech workers are, allegedly, the most boring dressers on earth, unless they're Jack Dorsey, in which case they occasionally look like high-fashion moon men.

item.title: San Francisco's Secretive, Exclusive Transportation System For Techies
item.description: When I first visited San Francisco last year, the thing that struck me most about the city was the massive fleet of fancy, unmarked buses that clogged up its streets in the mornings and evenings. The buses, which ferry tech workers from the heart of the city to the campuses of Google, Facebook and more, were an ever-present reminder of the Bay Area's glaring inequality — a transit system for the wealthiest residents only. For OneZero, Zara Stone took a closer look at the bus network and it's knock-on effects in the Bay Area.

item.title: The Internet Of Things Almost Starved My Cat
item.description: And other perils of the digital age.
item.kicker: CATS CAN HAVE A LITTLE TECH, AS A TREAT

item.title: Silicon Valley's Spandexed Biker Bros Are Going Extinct
item.description: Elite VC bike rides are giving way to chiller adventures.

item.title: Inside The Bay Area's Secretive $250 Million Private Transit System Just For Techies
item.description: 1,000 white-collar tech shuttles are stalling Bay Area public transit.

item.title: The Future Of Housing May Be $2,000 Dorm Rooms For Grownups. Some Have Doubts
item.description: "This is what passes for innovation in Silicon Valley. It's a dorm. It is a very expensive dorm."

item.title: How Foldable Displays Are Made
item.description: The first portable mobile phone weighed one kilogram, had to be held with two hands and took 10 hours to fully charge. We've come a long way from then. But what's up ahead?

item.title: Apple's Secret Monopoly
item.description: The App Store's gauzy success tale belies the reality of a company that now wields its enormous market power to bully, extort, and sometimes even destroy rivals and business partners alike.

item.title: Exclusive Survey Reveals Discrimination Against Visa Workers At Tech's Biggest Companies
item.description: OneZero conducted a 10,000-person poll to shed light on the plight of H-1B workers.

item.title: Google, Lyft And Uber: Voices Of The Tech Worker Revolution
item.description: Activists inside companies like Google, Lyft and Uber tell their stories.

item.title: When Mental Illness Memes Stop Being Funny
item.description: Online humor can be therapeutic, but it must be shared in certain ways
item.kicker: DON'T LET IT GET TO YOUR HEAD

item.title: Kombucha Slime Is An Edible Solution To The World's Plastic Problem
item.description: Produce can be wrapped in biodegradable "Scoby" sheets, then tossed or eaten.

item.title: How Google Got Its Employees To Eat Their Vegetables
item.description: The tech giant is engineering a way to encourage its employees to eat healthier  — and it might just help the rest of the country.

item.title: A Smear Of DNA Can Hold 10,000 Gigabytes Of Data
item.description: Facing a storage crisis, the US is investing $48 million to turn DNA into living hard drives.

item.title: I've Blocked Over 1,000 Brands On Twitter And I Can't Stop Them
item.description: As my brand block list swelled, I ran into a similar issue. Every day, I spent an hour or two diligently blocking brands, but more would surface to take their place. I could never quite reach the post-brand Twitter experience I craved.
